title: MVVM Introduction
narrative:
Swing-Tree allows you to create a Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) architecture
    based on 2 simple property interfaces: `Val`, and `Var`!

    `Val` is a read-only property, and `Var` is a read-write property.

    The state of both properties can be observed by the view using simple listeners.
    This happens automatically when you pass them to the Swing-Tree view.
    If you want to trigger an action when the property changes, you
    have to pass the `Var` property to the view and define a action
    for it inside of your view model.

extraInfo:
Note that we use a pre-made example view model here.
            Feel free to look at the source code of the view model
            to see what it is doing.

features.id: We can bind a enum property to a combo box and when the user selects an item, we notice it.

extraInfo:
You can conveniently bind a combo box to any type of property, 
            but there are 2 types of properties which should be used preferably:
            Enums and Strings. 
            And among these 2 you should always prefer enums over strings, because 
            they have a more manageable room of possible states...
            Only if the possible states are too many
            and not predictable during compile time, should you use strings.

features.id: View Models can be represented by properties.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you want to
            be able to swap out sub views at runtime. In this case it is useful
            to represent your view models as properties. 
            Simply implement the 'Viewable' interface in your view model and
            you can bind it to a view.
            When the property changes, the view will be updated automatically.

blocks.text: We create a view model.
A property storing the first view model.
Finally a view which binds to the view model property.
We build the component:
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We update the view model property.
The "sub-1" view is removed and the "sub-2" view is added.
The "super" view is still present.

features.id: View Models can be represented by property lists.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you want to
            be able to swap out sub views at runtime. In this case it is useful
            to represent your view models as property lists, especially if 
            one view consists of multiple sub views.
            Simply implement the 'Viewable' interface in your view model and
            you can bind it to a view using the "Vars" class wrapping your viewables.
            When the property list changes, the view will be updated automatically.

blocks.text: We create a view model.
We create 4 view models with 4 locally created views:
A property list storing the view models.
code: var vms = Vars.of(vm1, vm2, vm3, vm4)

blocks.text: Finally a view which binds to the view model property list.
We build the component:
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We remove something from the view model property list.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" view.
We remove something else from the view model property list but this time, for a change, use the index.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" and "sub-4" views.
We reintroduce "vm2"...
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-4" view.
We clear the view model property list.
We expect all views to be removed. (except for the "super" view)

features.id: View Models can be represented by tuples of models.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you want to
            be able to swap out sub views at runtime. In this case of value based view models
            it is useful to represent your view models as a tuple, especially if 
            one view consists of multiple sub views.
            Simply implement the functional 'Viewable' interface to supply a view
            for each model in the tuple and you can bind it to a view using the "Tuple" class.
            When the tuple changes, the view will be updated automatically.

blocks.text: We create a view model.
We create 4 view models with 4 locally created views:
A tuple storing the view models and a property storing the tuple.
code: var models = Tuple.of(vm1, vm2, vm3, vm4)

blocks.text: Finally a view which binds to the tuple of view models.
We build the component:
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We remove something from the tuple.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" view.
We remove something else from the view model property list but this time, for a change, use the index.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" and "sub-4" views.
We reintroduce "vm2"...
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-4" view.
We clear the view model tuple.
We expect all views to be removed. (except for the "super" view)

features.id: A dynamic property list based UI declaration can have layout constraints.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you want to

blocks.text: We create 4 view models with 4 locally created views:
A property list storing the view models.
code: var vms = Vars.of(vm1, vm2, vm3, vm4)

blocks.text: Finally a view which binds to the view model property list.
We build the component and get its layout.
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We unpack the layout manager for the "super" view.
Each sub view has the layout constraints "growx".
We remove something from the view model property list.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" view.
The layout manager was updated accordingly:
We remove something else from the view model property list but this time, for a change, use the index.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-1" and "sub-3" views.
Again, as expected, the layout manager was updated accordingly:
We reintroduce "vm1"...
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-3" view.
The layout manager also knows about the new constraint:
We clear the view model property list.
We expect all views to be removed. (except for the "super" view)
The layout manager reports no constraints.

features.id: A dynamic tuple based UI declaration can have layout constraints.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you want to
            be able to swap out sub views at runtime. In this case of value based modelling, 
            it is useful to represent your view models as tuples, especially if 
            one view consists of multiple sub views.
            Simply implement the functional 'Viewable' interface and
            supply a view for individual values in the tuple.
            When the tuple changes, the view will be updated automatically.

blocks.text: We create 4 view models with 4 locally created views:
A property storing a tuple of view models.
code: var models = Tuple.of(vm1, vm2, vm3, vm4)

blocks.text: Finally a view which binds to the view model property list.
We build the component and get its layout.
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We unpack the layout manager for the "super" view.
Each sub view has the layout constraints "growx".
We remove something from the view model property list.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-2" view.
The layout manager was updated accordingly:
We remove something else from the view model property list but this time, for a change, use the index.
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-1" and "sub-3" views.
Again, as expected, the layout manager was updated accordingly:
We reintroduce "vm1"...
We expect all views to be present except for the "sub-3" view.
The layout manager also knows about the new constraint:
We clear the view model property list.
We expect all views to be removed. (except for the "super" view)
The layout manager reports no constraints.

code: return UI.label("I am the sub view bound to: "+property.type().getSimpleName())
panel.components.every({it.text == "I am the sub view bound to: "+tuple.type().getSimpleName()})

blocks.text: We test the following operations:

tuple: Tuple.of("A", "B", "C").mapTo(StringWithId, s->new StringWithId(s, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.of("watch", "dominion", "or" ,"earthlings").mapTo(StringWithId, s->new StringWithId(s, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.of(2, 3, 5, 7, 11).mapTo(NumberWithId, i->new NumberWithId(i, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.of(0.47d, 3.5d, -2.22d, 84.3d).mapTo(NumberWithId, d->new NumberWithId(d, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.of(DayOfWeek.MONDAY, DayOfWeek.SATURDAY, DayOfWeek.THURSDAY, DayOfWeek.WEDNESDAY).mapTo(EnumWithId, d->new EnumWithId(d, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.ofNullable(String, "A", null, "B", "C", null).mapTo(StringWithId, s->new StringWithId(s, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.ofNullable(String, "watch", "dominion", "or" ,"earthlings").mapTo(StringWithId, s->new StringWithId(s, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.ofNullable(Integer, null, 2, 3, 5, null, 7, 11).mapTo(NumberWithId, i->new NumberWithId(i, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.ofNullable(Double, 0.47d, null, 3.5d, null, -2.22d, 84.3d).mapTo(NumberWithId, d->new NumberWithId(d, UUID.randomUUID()))
Tuple.ofNullable(DayOfWeek, DayOfWeek.MONDAY, null, DayOfWeek.SATURDAY, null).mapTo(EnumWithId, d->new EnumWithId(d, UUID.randomUUID()))

features.id: Binding a tuple property through `addAll` assumes full ownership over all sub-components.

extraInfo:
Binding multiple sub-views to a component using the tuple property `addAll(..)`
            method assumes full ownership over all sub-components. This means that you may not add
            anything else to the bound component.

features.id: A view model property may or may not exist, meaning its view may or may not be provided.

extraInfo:
In larger GUIs usually consist views which themselves consist of multiple
            sub views. This is also true for their view models which are usually
            structured in the same tree like fashion. 
            Often times however, your views are highly dynamic and you not only want to
            be able to swap out but also enable or disable a sub view (and its underlying view model) at runtime. 
            You can for example wrap your view model in a property and if it implements the "Viewable" interface
            the view can bind to it to dynamically regenerate the view. 
            If the property is empty, the view will not be provided.

blocks.text: We create a view model.
A view which binds to the view model and a viewer which provides the view.
We build the component:
We query the UI for the views and verify that the "super" and "sub-1" views are present.
We set the "moreUI" property to a view model which implements the "Viewable" interface (a "view provider").
code: moreUI.set("I am a dummy view model!")

blocks.text: We expect all views to be present.

features.id: A boolean property can be used to switch between 2 foreground colors.

extraInfo:
Using the 'withForegroundIf(Val<Boolean>, Color, Color)' method,
            you can switch between 2 foreground colors of a Swing component set dynamically
            if the boolean property is true or false.

blocks.text: We create a property modelling the color switch.
We create a 2 colors.
We declare a label with a red foreground color.
code: var ui = UI.label("Hello World!").withForegroundIf(isRed, red, green)

blocks.text: Then we build the component:
The label should have a red foreground color.
We change the boolean property to false.
The label should have a green foreground color.

extraInfo:
Using the 'withBackgroundIf(Val<Boolean>, Color, Color)' method,
            you can switch between 2 background colors of a Swing component set dynamically

blocks.text: We create a property modelling the color switch.
We create a 2 colors.
We declare a label with a red background color.
code: var ui = UI.label("Hello World!").withBackgroundIf(isRed, red, green)

blocks.text: Then we build the label component:
The label should have a red background color.
We change the boolean property to false.
The label should have a green background color.

features.id: A boolean property can be used to set or reset a foreground color.

extraInfo:
Using the 'withForegroundIf(Val<Boolean>, Color)' method,
            you can set or reset the foreground color of a Swing component dynamically
            if the boolean property is true or false.

blocks.text: We create a property modelling the color switch.
We create a label with a yellow background color.
Now we build the component:
We remember the original foreground color.
The label should have the original foreground color.
We change the boolean property to true.
The label should have a yellow foreground color because the boolean property is true.
We change the boolean property to false.
Again, the label should have the original foreground color.
